metadata.title: Increasing attacks by Israeli settlers on Palestinians in the West Bank
metadata.author: ABC News

transcript: Welcome back. While tonight a tenuous peace is holding in Gaza, there is concern about increasing violence in the West Bank. October saw the highest number of Israeli settler attacks since records began. Increasingly large and violent gangs of Israeli settlers are attacking farmers, civilians, residents, driving people from their homes, burning businesses, even a mosque. So, what's being done about it? Chief foreign correspondent Ian Panel has a look in tonight's prime focus. Gangs of violent Israeli settlers running riot in the West Bank spreading terror in Palestinian communities. Brutal assaults caught on camera. Oh, come on. Don't you hit her. Roughly the size of Delaware, the West Bank has been occupied by Israel since the War of 1967. It's home to millions of Palestinians and a rising number of Israeli settlements considered illegal under international law. Since the ceasefire in Gaza, there's been a surge in violence here. Committed by extremist groups of settlers. October was the most violent months of attacks since UN records began in 2006. Israeli human rights groups, activists, and the opposition are accusing the government of stoking the attacks. And the Israeli army has been repeatedly accused of standing by and letting it happen. What it feels like is that the settlers now recognize that they run the place. The West Bank village of Tasiah is a unique place in the Israeli occupied West Bank. The majority of residents here are Palestinian American and it's long been a target for settler attacks. This is uh Yaser's olive farmland we just looked. Independent journalist Jasper Nathaniel has been taking regular trips to the West Bank since October the 7th, 2023. That's Shilo there. And then that over there, what is it called? The other one. Adial. Adiad, another settlement, and all this land in between them is Terasiah. On October 19th this year, Jasper and other activists forced to flee when settlers advanced on Palestinian farmers harvesting olives in the foothills of the town. Spotting a group of soldiers on the hill, Jasper covered his phone camera and ask them for protection. We just need help getting out because the settlers over there are blocking us and this is the only other way. Where are you going? Just back to Terasiah. He says they agreed to help. Yeah, just want to go home. But the help never came. Jasper went to help a Palestinian whose cartras had been slashed by the settler gang. You going to push? About 4 minutes after the military had driven away, a mob of dozens, if not over a hundred masked settlers appear from over the hill. Hey. Hey, press. press, American press, and they start throwing huge rocks, running straight towards me. They're wielding huge clubs, and I realize this is an ambush. They're literally right behind us. Oh, he's he's right here. He's not smashing. After escaping back to his car, the pair are suddenly trapped, surrounded on all sides by the armed mob. Are the doors locked? Then this. You got it. Oh, come on. Don't hit her. Hey. Oh my god. Hey. Hey. The settler attacks an unarmed woman helping with the harvest. 55year-old Asaf Abu Alia was brutally beaten, suffering a brain injury. We met her a few weeks later recovering at home. The vicious attack drawing international criticism. After several weeks, the Israeli police arrested a suspect who remains in custody. Hundreds of settlers have taken part in the violent attacks, but only a handful have been arrested and even few are convicted. Israel says the attacks are committed by a minority, but human rights groups have accused the IDF of either turning a blind eye or being complicit in settler attacks. Do you feel you're succeeding in keeping the peace? Well, we've seen a lot of success in counterterrorism, but we've also seen a rise in uh those clashes between civilians in uh in recent weeks. It is something that we spoke about uh head of central command and the head of the army the chief of general staff spoke about and said uh this does not go according to our values. This is unacceptable. I just want to take exception with your characterization of these uh incidents as clashes. If a group of um people go onto someone's property and either force them out, set fire to it, uh beat them, uh destroy property, is it fair to describe that as a terrorist act? Well, I'm not I'm not here to give names. I'm here to say that that act is unacceptable. If I can bring your attention to an incident that took place uh last month during the olive harvest in uh to Messiah. The charge against the IDF uh by Jasper Nathaniel is that he told the IDF that they feared for their lives, they the activists and uh the Palestinian farm workers. uh and yet the IDF uh drove away and did not respond uh promptly while the incident was taking place. That seems to fly in the face of of of what you're telling me. I saw that video and um I want to say that doesn't represent the values of the idea. It's not who we are and it's something that will be dealt with and it is being dealt with. Can you tell me how many settlers have been charged and imprisoned or punished as a result of violence uh over the last months? Well, I think that's a question to be asked to uh Israeli police and I say it's not so much uh something that the IDF is involved in that side of the process. Um and I don't have the current answer for you. We put that exact same question to the Israeli police, but they pushed responsibility back to the army, telling us the IDF were responsible for the real-time prevention and handling of violent incidents throughout the region, including situations involving Palestinian and Israeli individuals. Asaf Abu Alia showing us the settlements around her village. It's been a period of devastating violence, one that now threatens to undermine plans to bring about a broader regional peace. It's hard to like explain to people what it feels like to be in these communities in these olive fields right now because you are basically almost always encircled by settler outposts. You know, they have strategically built their little fortresses um to give them position to launch attacks. A tentative ceasefire in Gaza, but the West Bank is on fire and hopes for a wider peace deal now at risk. and peaceful Palestinians who've lived here for generations are not only afraid but see their dream of a homeland slipping away.

key_facts: October 2023 saw the highest number of Israeli settler attacks in West Bank since UN records began in 2006.
The West Bank has been occupied by Israel since the 1967 War.
The West Bank is roughly the size of Delaware.
The West Bank is home to millions of Palestinians and a growing number of Israeli settlements.
Israeli settlements in the West Bank are considered illegal under international law.
Since the Gaza ceasefire, there has been a surge in violence in the West Bank.
Violence in the West Bank is increasingly committed by extremist settler groups.
Tasiah is a West Bank village with a majority Palestinian American population.
Tasiah has long been a target for settler attacks.
On October 19, 2023, settlers advanced on Palestinian farmers harvesting olives in Tasiah.
Journalist Jasper Nathaniel was present during an attack and sought military protection.
Soldiers were seen on a hill but did not intervene when settlers attacked.
After soldiers left, a mob of over 100 masked settlers appeared and ambushed activists.
Settlers threw large rocks and wielded clubs during the attack.
Unarmed woman Asaf Abu Alia, aged 55, was brutally beaten and suffered a brain injury.
Asaf Abu Alia was recovering at home several weeks after the attack.
The Israeli police arrested one suspect in connection with the attack.
Only a small number of settlers have been arrested despite hundreds involved in attacks.
Fewer still have been convicted for their roles in violent incidents.
Human rights groups accuse the IDF of either ignoring or being complicit in settler violence.
The IDF claims it does not condone such acts and says they go against its values.
The IDF chief of general staff acknowledged rising civilian clashes as unacceptable.
Jasper Nathaniel reported that IDF forces drove away but failed to respond during active attacks.
The Israeli police stated the IDF is responsible for real-time prevention of violent incidents.
Settler outposts are strategically built to enable attacks on Palestinian communities.
key_opinions: The settlers now feel they run the place in the West Bank.
The attacks are not just 'clashes' but constitute acts of terrorism.
The IDF's failure to respond promptly reflects poorly on its values.
The situation threatens broader regional peace efforts.
Palestinians living in the area feel encircled and vulnerable.
The dream of a Palestinian homeland is slipping away due to ongoing violence.
The current level of violence undermines trust in Israeli security forces.
The lack of accountability for settlers suggests systemic tolerance.
The IDF’s response appears inconsistent with its stated mission.
International criticism is warranted given the scale and nature of the violence.
The government may be indirectly enabling settler aggression.
The military’s inaction fuels fear among civilians and activists.
The portrayal of violence as 'clashes' downplays its severity.
Peaceful communities feel abandoned by state institutions.
The presence of settler outposts creates an environment of constant threat.
key_datapoints: October 2023 recorded the most violent month of settler attacks since 2006.
Over 100 masked settlers participated in a single ambush incident.
One suspect arrested in connection with the attack on Asaf Abu Alia.
Asaf Abu Alia is 55 years old and suffered a brain injury.
The attack occurred during the olive harvest season in October 2023.
Hundreds of settlers have taken part in violent attacks across the region.
Only a handful of settlers have been arrested following these incidents.
Fewer than ten settlers have been convicted for related violence.
The West Bank is approximately the same size as Delaware.
The IDF chief of general staff publicly condemned recent civilian clashes.
The IDF claims it has seen success in counterterrorism operations.
The Israeli police deferred responsibility to the IDF regarding incident handling.
The incident in Messiah occurred last month during the olive harvest.
Jasper Nathaniel made regular trips to the West Bank starting October 7, 2023.
The video footage of the attack was reviewed by the IDF leadership.
